Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 05:30PM lisa-e wrote: Emme, you should get a referral to a le therapist.  LindaLou, the pictures are very informative.  Thank you so much for posting them!
Posts.Title: VISIBLE SIGNS OF LYMPHEDEMA - A PICTORIAL LindaLou53 glennie19

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2009 12:12PM lisa-e wrote: I was very busty, with dense breasts. I could not feel either of the invasive tumors I had. On the other hand, none of the professionals who examined me felt them either, with the exception of my surgeon. He didn't feel a lump, but he felt a dimple on the underside of my breast that was caused by a small (.8cm) tumor. The only thing that showed up on a mammogram was an area of DCIS.
Posts.Title: for large-busted women... admom thegoodfight

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 10:50AM lisa-e wrote: The risk of getting breast cancer increases with the use of birth  control pills; however, I can't think of any studies that indicate birth control pills cause cancer.   If you used birth control pills, I wouldn't waste any time beating yourself up about it.  After all, birth control pill have many good side effects, the least of which is the prevention of unwanted pregnancy.  That can only be a good thing. By the way, I never used birth control pills or  took hormones when I was perimenopausal.  I still got a highly er+ (99%)  bc.
Posts.Title: EXTENDED ORAL CONTRACEPTIVE USE & BREAST CANCER...RELATED? AmyMarie89 AmyMarie89

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 02:58PM lisa-e wrote: Badboob, I am looking at the abstract for the original study ("Weight Lifting in Women with Breast-Cancer Related Lymphedema," Schmitz et al).  The results indicated that the weight-lifting group and the control group had a similar increase in limb swelling.  However, the weight-lifting group had greater improvements in self-reported severity of lymphedema and a lower incidence of lymphedema exacerbations as assessed by a certified lympedema specialist. The orignal study was published in the New England Journal of Medicine.  You can download it and read it for yourself.    As I said in my previous post, I am glad to see such research and I hope there is more research on le.  I would prefer to know there is research indicating the risk precuations I take actually do cut my risk rather than following them because that is just what you to prevent le.
Posts.Title: Susan Love proclaims no need for lymphedema risk reductions kira TammyLou

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 02:13PM lisa-e wrote: I have mild le.  I read both Dr. Love's article on the weight lifting study and her comment about le risk reduction practices and I agree with nskyes.  I think there should be more study of le and what practices really reduce risk and what practices don't reduce risk.  I do follow the time-worn precautions regarding blood pressure and needles, but I would like to know if the precautions are really necessary or not.    I don't think questioning the necessity of these practices through a properly designed study is insenstive to me.
Posts.Title: Susan Love proclaims no need for lymphedema risk reductions kira TammyLou

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 04:34PM - edited Oct 6, 2009 04:35PM by lisa-e I read the Schmidtz study and I do think that Dr. Love correctly interpreted the Schmidtz study.  Also, there was an improvement in both self-reported symptoms and in flare ups as assessed by a certified le specialist , according to the study, not just an improvement in self-reported symptoms.  I agree the study was carefully designed, but I do not think the conditions are impossible or even that difficult to replicate. It may be hard to design studies on le, but I still would like to see such studies.  As I have had lymph nodes out on bilaterally, I find the standard risk reduction precautions to be very difficult to adhere to.  Every doctor's visit, every blood test is a mine field that has to be carefully negotiated.  I would like to know if the precautions are really necessary - or if I am falsely relying on a body of knowledge that is based experience and tradition.   I would like to rely on both evidence and the body of knowledge.   If we don't question the precautions and le treatments we won't make any progress and I don't see the harm in suggesting other women may feel the same way I do. I wonder if you could do a retrospective study looking at breast cancer patients who have had lymphnode removal and compare those who developed le and those who didn't.  What risk precautions did each group take?
Posts.Title: Susan Love proclaims no need for lymphedema risk reductions kira TammyLou

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 09:13AM lisa-e wrote: I'll grant the fact that Dr. Love's comment was flip, but a flip comment is not enough to make me stop taking the risk precautions I do. Good research would, however, and that is what I want to see. I am happy just to hear the suggestion that there is the need for more research. Sometimes I feel like I am experimenting on myself, finding out what I works to control my le and what causes a flare up. I am a climber and while some would say I should have stopped to reduce my risk for le, I found I was unwilling to. After my mast, I started climbing again, slowly, wearing a sleeve. I had my arm measurements checked and there was no change, so decided to keep on climbing. But the whole time I felt like I was my own experiment. So reading the experiment about weight lifting was a big deal to me - it told me I was on the right track - slow progression and compression with monitoring. Binney, thank's for the link. And Member of the Club, thanks for posting Dr. Love's response to your email. I do agree with you that she needs input on the section on le.
Posts.Title: Susan Love proclaims no need for lymphedema risk reductions kira TammyLou

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 09:06PM lisa-e wrote: Well, I may not have eaten with my breasts, let alone peed with them, pooped with them, breathed with them, but I still miss them, greatly,  after two years.    What makes it worse is that I never felt (and still don't feel) like I have a potentially fatal disease.  I can't tell myself that I am better off without my breasts, that they tried to kill me, because I don't really believe it.
Posts.Title: This makes me feel terrible...anyone else? shockedat39 chrishat

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 01:44PM - edited Aug 21, 2009 01:46PM by lisa-e debncy, it was slightly uncomfortable having the wire inserted for my wire guided biopsy, but I didn't really notice it after it was inserted.  They coiled the wire up and taped it to my breast.  I had the wire inserted in the morning at about 8 am, but my surgery was delayed until about 3 in the afternoon.  The funny thing about the whole experience was when I stood up after having the wire inserted.  I looked at this wire sticking out of my chest and just cracked up as it looked so funny to me.  The radiologist looked at me like I was absolutely insane.   My advice is see if you can have something to drink in the morning.  I was so dehydrated by the time they started to put in the iv that it was difficult to find a vien.  I had a big bruise.   As you know your surgery will take place in the afternoon, you may be able to have a drink and will feel much better.  I hope things go well!
Posts.Title: does the wire hurt in an excisional biopsy?? debnyc JCinAZ

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 09:44AM lisa-e wrote: Barry, I think my son developed RSD after an undiagnosed fracture in his foot.  His feet burned and he couldn't wear socks or shoes and obviously had a great deal of trouble walking.  I don't think he had problems with the joints being stiff or frozen, but did have temperature changes and skin color changes in his feet.  It was hard to get a diagnosis.  They wound up doing a sympathetic nerve block to diagnosis it.  He took high doses of neurontin for several years, then weaned himself off it.  A difficult process. but he was concerned about its effect on his mental agility. It is hard to get a doctor to look at the whole picture.  They want to look at their specialty, where they feel comfortable and often have tunnel vision.  When I was being diagnosed, I was also seeing a osteopathic doctor.  I was able to talk with her at length about the decisions I was being faced with and found that very helpful.  A doctor can give you your options and the pros and cons of each option, but you are still the one who has to decide.
Posts.Title: How serious is stage 1, low grade cancer? Hindsfeet annettek

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 05:33AM lisa-e wrote: Barry, my son was diagnosed with RSD and all I can say is that it is a lousy diagnosis.    I don't know all of the ramifications of the disease and surgery, but I do know that any minor injury  would cause a flare up that took a long time to get other control.  When he was diagnosed twelve years ago, he was told that it would 'burn out' eventually.  I don't know if his RSD has done that, but it is easier to control these days.  In any case, I can understand your caution about surgery and hope your decisions become obvious.
Posts.Title: How serious is stage 1, low grade cancer? Hindsfeet annettek

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 05:41PM lisa-e wrote: Joyce, I know what you mean about wanting to think things through. I started considering my options when I had a second round of biopsies after a lumpectomy and SNB. Luckily, my conclusion that a mastectomy was my only option agreed with my doctor's reccomendations. I don't know if the suspicous areas you having tested are in the same breast that you had the lumpectomy or not. If you have a second cancer, a mastectomy may be your only option. However, if the second cancer is your other breast, you could have a lumpectomy. Don't rush into a mastectomy. Reconstruction does not give you breasts with sensation. I miss that sensation and think it is worth trying to preserve. Anyway, homealone is right that the results may well be b9. If not, make a decision based on the results of biopsies. Don't make a decision on the basis of emotion only. I hope you don't need to make any decisions and all is normal.
Posts.Title: decision JoyceR lisa-e

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 06:55AM lisa-e wrote: cleomoon, I had a bilateral mastectomy without reconstruction in September 2008. I don't have pain, but my chest is tight and I am aware of the scars. I was very bust pre mastectomy, so my scars run from my sternum to under my arms. The are slightly above what was my bra line. I also have two smaller scars that run from mid chest to the main scars. A plastic surgeon helped plan the incisions. the goal was to get rid of all extra skin, but to leave a better 'breast cone' if I ever decide to have reconstruction. I have full range of motion or close to it-never thought to measure it before surgery. I am not sure my chest will ever feel normal, just like anyother part of my body. I stretch a lot and have seen a physical therapist who specializes in working on scars. At this point, I think that the tightness is something I will have to work with on an ongoing basis. I can deal with it.
Posts.Title: How long after BM til there is no pain etc? cleomoon ddlatt

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2015 06:54AM - edited Dec 8, 2015 12:02PM by lisa-e I tend to think a breast MRI before surgery is a good idea, to determine the extent of disease, especially if you have dense breasts. Of course, that is based on my experience. I asked my oncologist about an MRI when I met with him before my surgery. He said he didn't recommend one as the rate of false positives was too high. I was happy enough to go along with him. When my surgeon examined me before surgery (for an area of high grade DCIS), he felt a dimple and decided to remove what was causing the skin retraction. That turned out to be a small invasive tumor, not seen on mammograms. The radiation oncologist asked me to have an MRI before starting rads. I did, had four more biopsies, and it was found that I had another invasive tumor. It was agreed that my only surgical option was a mastectomy. Having an MRI pre surgery would have meant I could have had one surgery. It would have saved me money and time off work.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed, no MRI? NewDay123 NewDay123

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 10:46PM lisa-e wrote: I would advise you to think very carefully about a mastectomy.  Remember, that the surgery is not reversible.  I had to have a mastectomy because I had multi centric cancer and as a did not want to have reconstruction opted to have a bilateral mastectomy.   I really, really miss having my breasts.  Reconstructed breasts or prosthetic boobs are not the same as your own breasts, they don't have any feeling.  No sexual feelings.  There is a brief discussion on this site about mastectomy versus lumpectomy that gives on overview of things to consider.
Posts.Title: How do you decide? keepnfaith bdavis

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2010 04:58PM lisa-e wrote: First of all, you won't look god awful after surgery.  Different, but not god awful.    Second, if you are not going to use a PS ask your surgeon about what he plans to do, how is planning the incisions to deal with the extra skin.  Make sure he understands what your goal is, appearance wise.
Posts.Title: A need for a PS? Halah chele

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2010 08:49PM lisa-e wrote: Winterstorm, my bs asked a plastic surgeon to assist with my bi mast even though I didn't have reconstruction.  I made it clear to him what I would like the cosmetic outcome to be - a return to my pre-pubescent chest.  He asked the plastic surgeon to assist because I was quite, quite busty and it would have been very difficult to achieve this outcome without planning of my incisions.    My incisions are like the ones shown in the link you posted.  Instead I have vertical scars that run from about where my nipples would be if I had any.  These vertical scars connect to horizontal scars that run from my sternum to my underarms, along my 'bra line',  The results are pretty good - no ears.  My chest is lumpy and bumpy, but that is due to my tendency to form scar tissue not due to excess skin.  One thing that I remember the ps wrote in her operative notes is that the incisions were planned to give more natural results if I ever decided to have reconstruction. If I remember correctly, you mentioned you were pretty busty in a previous post.  So perhaps a consult with a ps isn't a bad idea.  I would also ask your bs why he referred you to a ps.
Posts.Title: A need for a PS? Halah chele

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2010 01:54PM lisa-e wrote: Aw Leah, I am sorry.   It is good you have a referral - how long before you see the le therapist.  Re your questions, you can elevate your arm if you sleep on the side that is not having problems.  Put a pillow between your body and your arm.  Another alternative is to use a body pillow - drape your arm over it.  I don't know about wearing the sleeve at this point - is it still the right size, etc?   If I were in your situation, waiting to see a le therapist, I think I wouldn't wear it but would monitor my arm carefully in case I was developing a case of cellulitis.  If you are, that is an emergency.
Posts.Title: well, dang Leah_S kira

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2010 10:02PM lisa-e wrote: Momma of three, I agree with every one who thinks a bilateral mastectomy for ADH is a bit much.  Look at this way - a mastectomy can have permanent side effects, include pain and lymphedema, in addition to the fact that you would loose all sexual sensation.  Your ADH may or may not develop into anything else, but why risk the side effects of a mastectomy (or even a re-excision) for a benign condition.  If you had a cancer dx, then the benefits of treatment would out weight the risks and side effects.   I've had a mastectomy and I can tell you from personal experience that it is not something to do lightly.   At least I can tell myself that it was  necessary to treat my cancer.  I couldn't do that if I only had ADH.
Posts.Title: ADH- treatment options momma_of_3 vmudrow

Seattle, WA 98105 USA Phone: 206 838-0600 Fax: 206 838-0650 I don't know about the flight home, but I didn't need pillows to come home from the hospital via car. The trip home was rather long too, with stops at the drug store and the grocery store.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 08:46PM lisa-e wrote: Nancy, I had a lumpectomy, snb, and an excisional biopsy before the rad onc I saw asked me to get an MRI, before starting rads.  Three biopsies later I had another bc diagnosis.  I wound up having a BMX (and being able to skip rads). Now when some tells me they are newly diagnosed with breast cancer, my advice is get an MRI before making any decisions about surgery.  So, while it is frustrating, be glad that you had the MRI before your lumpectomy.   It may save you a second surgery.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 08:19AM lisa-e wrote: KerryMac, you said something I appreciate, about being dx at an earlier stage being harder in some ways.  I tend to think you are right; I was dx at stage one, grade one and while a mx was a given given the fact my bc was multicentric chemo didn't offer me much of an advantage, so I opted not to have it.  But I still wonder about my decision.   I think anyone, with any diagnosis, has the right to complain about bc treatment.  It just sucks.  However, I understand what Molly is saying about people using the dx as a opportunity to say poor me.   And there is a difference between complaining about treatment and side effects, versus getting stuck in a pity party.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 07:35PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 11:25AM by lisa-e I just wanted to chime in and say that I have one of the sleeves from the Lymphedema Sleeve Co.  It is a bilateral sleeve and has the band that goes accross the back.  It is wonderful as it does not cut into your upper arm and also does not slip down.  I have worn it to work and it looks elegant unlike ordinary sleeves.  I have also worn it while exercising and it works quite well for that application.   Cookiegal, you may really like this sleeve.  One nice thing is that the material has silver ions in it, to help prevent infection.  Good luck!  (edited for spelling...)

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2009 07:10PM lisa-e wrote: Caren, I understand that you are post treatment. If I were in your situation, I would get a second and third opinion. Mastecotmy and reconsruction are major surgeries and I would want to make sure it is necessary. I had a mastectomy, without reconstruction, after being diagnosed with multi centric cancer. I had the surgery because it was necessary to treat my cancers. But I miss my breasts, I miss their sensation and I hate the fact that my scars are uncomfortable and serve as a constant reminder. I think close monitoring and even possible biopsy's would be better than loosing your breasts without a good reason.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 11:54PM - edited Feb 11, 2012 11:56PM by lisa-e Barbie, the inaccurate statement is that everyone has a 50% chance of recurrence.  You are talking about one way looking at of recurrence, ie either you have a recurrence or you don't.   That is one way of looking at it, but that does not mean every woman diagnosed with breast cancer has a 50% chance of recurrence.  Statement like that irritate the hell out of me because they feed fear.   Initial BC dx with dcis & idc after lumpectomy & snb in 6/08. in 8/08 dx with multicentric bc (idc) after mri. had bilat mastecomy in 9/08 w/o reconstruction
Posts.Title: Why am I only ok talking to stage III ladies?feeling like a jerk Josiekat lkc

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 02:21AM - edited Feb 12, 2012 02:22AM by lisa-e Pickle, saying recurrence is a crapshoot is different than saying every woman dx'd with breast cancer has a 50% chance of recurrence.  Every woman has a chance of recurrence but I think the biology of the tumor is a good indicator of the chances.

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2011 09:32AM - edited Apr 18, 2011 09:33AM by lisa-e luvvyk46, I had a spot compression mammogram because to look at an area of calcifications and an area of architectural distortion.   After the spot compression mammogram, the radiologist said that the pattern of the calcifications indicated DCIS and I should have a biopsy.  I did and it was DCIS.  However, in the spot compression mammogram, the area of architectural distortion did not appear to be abnormal.  In reality, it was a 0.8 mm IDC.  My surgeon felt the skin retraction it was causing, so removed it when I had a lumpectomy for the DCIS (they were in different quadrants of my breast). Like you, I had dense breasts.  Therefore, my rad onc asked me to get an MRI before I began radiation.  It turned out I had another tumor.  They were able to find the area with ultra sound for a biopsy.   If I were you, I would push for an MRI, if you can find a radiologist who has read many of them.
Posts.Title: spot compression mammography luvvyk46 luvvyk46

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2009 05:48PM lisa-e wrote: Otter, not to be an alarmist, but has it been determined that the balance difficulties are related to post-chemo neuropathy?   It seems to me that a new change in balance should be evaluated. My mothers lung cancer was not diagnosed until it spread to her spine.  The presenting symptoms were changes in her balance, not pain.  I also know my primary care doc tests balance during  annual exams.   I haven't asked him specifically what he is looking for, but a lot of things  influence balance.

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 01:18PM - edited Sep 4, 2009 04:56PM by lisa-e After being dx with multi centric bc in my right breast, I was told a mastectomy was my only surgical option.  I decided to have a bilateral mastectomy because I did not want to have reconstruction.  As I was quite busty, I would have been unbalanced.    Fear of future breast cancer in my left breast was not a factor in my decision. I don't regret having a bilateral mast; however I miss having breasts.  I'd think long and hard about how much you will miss the sensation of your breasts when you make your decision.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2012 10:53PM lisa-e wrote: MomToFive, I hope you've made an appointment with Planned Parenthood.  December is not that far away.  You should make an appointment, if you haven't already, and make sure you are on their cancelation list.  Make sure they know about your symptoms.  Call them everyday to see if they have any cancelations.  Be ready to drop everything and go if they have an opening. The ER doesn't have to diagnosis you; they have to make sure you are stable ( i.e. not in immediate danger of dying) and will refer you to a breast surgeon.
Posts.Title: I dont know what to do MomToFive MomToFive

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2009 05:18PM - edited Jun 19, 2009 05:18PM by lisa-e Beth, I had a bi mast in September.  I waited until January to get prosthesis and bras.  I went to a local mastectomy supply shop.  I already knew the owner/fitter because I ordered some camisoles through the store before the surgery.  The whole process was amusing to me, I think because I had sort of gotten used to being flat chested.  When I tried on the first set of forms I burst out laughing -  those 'bumps' on my chest really looked funny to me.  And when I wore the forms in public for the first time, I felt like a teenager.  These days I usually save my forms for formal occasions. Anyway, if you are nervous I suggest making the appointment for your fitting in person so you get a feel for the store.  Also, take a friend along if you think that would make you feel better.  Finally, I do agree with the folks who say there is no need get forms before you want to.  And if you never want to, don't worry about it.
Posts.Title: Nervouse about getting prosthesis for the first time BethHG nagem

Posts.Content: May 19, 2009 09:50AM lisa-e wrote: LIsa, IDC does not always mean chemo.  The decision regarding chemo is made based upon the cancer's size and agressiveness.   If a cancer has a low chance of recurring, chemo does not offer much in the way of reducing the chances of recurrance.  The Oncotype test is often done to determine the chances of recurrance in node negarive, er  positive cancers.   I did not have chemo.  I am taking tamoxifen.
Posts.Title: why do I need chemo after lumpectomy with clean nodes aaronali12 jotti

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2008 07:18AM - edited Dec 17, 2008 07:19AM by lisa-e Janis, good luck with the surgery!  I don't normally post in this forum, but your posts about your hip caught my attention.  I had a hip replacement this past April, due to avascular necrosis.  The recovery was work (physical therapy) but I had very little post surgical pain and certainly my hip didn't hurt afterwards.  I am glad I had the surgery!  I hope you will have similar results.
Posts.Title: I will be offline for a few days.. Fitztwins LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2011 09:06AM lisa-e wrote: If you have multiple tumors, each tumor would require its own oncotype test. I had two invasive tumors and had each one tested, with different results.  In general, the treatment for multicentric breast cancer is based on the largest tumor.  That doesn't make sense to me, as each tumor can have its own biology.  My onc agreed with me, in principal, then argued a bit with me when I wanted a onctoype test for my second tumor, as he had never heard of insurance paying for two oncotype tests.  I told him to humor me - that I would insist on it before agreeing to chemo.  As it turned out the oncotype score for the second and larger tumor was lower than the score for the smaller tumor.  I felt comfortable opting out of chemo. One thing about making decisions, my onc told me some women would have chemo for a one percent reduction in their changes of recurrence.  I told him I would not agree to chemo for that small of an inprovement.  People's tolerence for risk differ,

Dawn, I also like the purple top!  It is very becoming.  And thank you very much for telling us where you got the purple jacket.    I hate, hate shopping, so I need ideas of where to look for styles that would look good on me now.

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2008 02:50PM lisa-e wrote: I had an MRI after a lumpectomy, before beginning radiation, at the request of my radiation oncologist.  The MRI found four suspect areas, so I had four biopsies.  I did have a second invasive cancer, so had a bilateral mastectomy.   I asked my medical oncologist about an MRI before I had the lumpectomy.  He said he didn't like to order them because of the high number of false positives.  I didn't pursue it, although in hindsight I wish I had. I could have had one surgery instead of two.  However, the time lag gave me time to consider my options and play "what if".  By the time I had the MRI and biopsies, I knew I would have a bilateral mastectomy if any of the biopsy results were positive. I think it is reasonable to demand biopsies of the suspicious areas.  Given the high number of false positives with MRI, there may be nothing to be concerned about.  If you do have another diagnosis, you can take it from there.    Good luck on Friday!
Posts.Title: 2 Types of Cancer? - MRI better than Mammograms? hope4cure lisa-e

Posts.Content: May 6, 2010 10:36AM lisa-e wrote: I decided not  to have reconstruction because the different methods all have major draw backs as far as I am concerned.  The idea of putting an implant under my pec muscles made me very, very uneasy.  I am very active (rock climb and hike) so do not want to interfere with the function of the pec muscles.  Lat or tram flaps would have been out of the question for the same reason.  I might have considered DIEP reconstruction except it is such a major surgery.   I had two surgeries in the six months before I had my mastectomy - a total hip replacement and a lumpectomy, an excisional biopsy and an SNB.  I was tired of surgeries and didn't want to sign up for more.  Also, I would have not been able to have a DIEP done locally.  The idea of having to find a plastic surgeon and fight with my insurance company to go out of network was overwhelming.
Posts.Title: What made you decide not to recon lucylou 3jaysmom

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2008 07:08PM lisa-e wrote: Wallycat - I told my surgeon if I don't have reconstruction I would like to be like my pre-pubescent self again.  He understood. Erica, I am giving myself this weekend to come to a decision.   I am going to a local store that sells mastectomy bras etc. tomorrow.  A friend who also has bc  said that was helpful.   She chose reconstrution and her new breasts are very nice looking.  She still has expanders, but even so her breasts feel pretty natural to me.  On the other hand, I know another woman who chose not to have recontruction and she looks good to me too.   A hard decision for me.

I appreciate hearing about everyone's experiences ... very helpful to me.  I've decided against reconstruction - mainly because I don't think it is a good idea to put a foreign body between my pecs.  I've told my surgeon not to leave any extra skin.  So we will see - if I need scar revision, so be it...

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 06:44PM lisa-e wrote: Sparrow,  I think my Mri took about 45 minutes or so. I don't think it matters what you wear as longas you don't wear anything with metal - belt buckle, buttons, earrings, etc.  Normally when you get an MRI, you are taken to a changing room where you can change into what ever is required and where you can lock your stuff up.   When I had a breast MRI, I was given a gown to wear into the room with the MRI. I took it off while the tech postioned me - then she covered me with a blanket.      I found the breast MRI was a lot easier than the MRI I had for my hip.  I didn't find it uncomfortable to lay face down, while I was having muscle spasms from lying in the postion required for the hip MRI.  I just did a lot of deep breathing and got very relaxed.   It was not an awful experience. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2009 06:49PM lisa-e wrote: Member of the club, I wonder if your husband's understanding of breast cancer is better than his understanding of LE.  I know my husband doesn't really understand LE and his attitude is similiar to your husband's.  However, he has a similar attitude to breast cancer.  He just doesn't get any of it and doesn't really want to, despite his willingness to go to doctor's appointments with me and helpfulness after surgeries.  He wants to think to think my breast cancer is cured and that my chance of recurrence are zero rather than the 15% or so I estimated, based on my oncotype score.  He also wants to think LE isn't a big deal, even though I have told him it is something I will deal with for the rest of my life.  Head in the sand, maybe . . .
Posts.Title: LE and Loved Ones Member_of_the_Club lionessdoe

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 01:46PM lisa-e wrote: I have three of these sleeves (I liked them so much that I ordered two more after I got one through my insurance).  They are very elegant, non medical looking and very comfortable.  As my arms are cone shaped (upper arms larger than my forearms, I tend to have problems with sleeves slipping down.  These (soledia slimming sleeves) don't.  Sleeveninja mentioned that they are heavily textured.  When I take the sleeve off,  i have a chevron pattern on my arms.  Per their literature and my le therapist that is a sign the sleeve is working to promote lymph flow. The design seems to encourage the lymph to move to the para-spinal nodes I know the pattern is more pronounced on the days when it feels like my le is flaring a bit.    Sleeveninja also mentioned that the bilateral sleeve is not technically A LE compression garment.  That is correct, but it is an active garment - promoting lymph flow.   I wear them when climbing and exercising.  I like them a lot more than the juzzo sleeves I used to wear.

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2009 05:26PM lisa-e wrote: Michele, I am not as young as you but I had a bilateral mastectomy and decided not to have reconstruction.  I am happy with the decision, although I do feel like it was the best of a bad lot of alternatives. I remember my surgeon telling me that the decision to have reconstruction or to opt out would have to be my own.  During this period, when I was making up my mind my dh refrained from telling me what he preferred.  After I decided against reconstruction, he said that he would have preferred that I have reconstruction.  However; after he learned more about what was involved and why I decided against reconstruction, he was fine with my decision. Take your time; if you aren't certain about reconstruction at this point, don't let anyone talk you into it.   You have to be comfortable with your choice and it is not your responsibility to make any one else happy.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2009 01:36PM lisa-e wrote: I always hated getting mammograms because the reports always included a disclaimer, stating I had dense breasts which were "not suited to mammograms.'    As it tuned out neither of the two idc tumors I had were detected via mammogram.   My surgeon felt a dimple caused by one tumor and did an excisional biopsy when I had a lumpectomy for dcis found on via mammogram.  After my radiation oncologist asked me to get a MRI, to check for the extent of disease, a second tumor was found.  Incidentally, the final pathology report after my mastectomy also showed another area of dcis that did not show up on mammogram, ultrasound or MRI.   So yeah, I think the MRI was a real good idea.  I wish my medical oncologist had ordered one before the initial surgery.  I asked him about an MRI and he said he thought the rate of false positives was too high.  I did not push for one at the time, but in retrospect I should have.  I am so glad the radiation oncologist asked me to get one.

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2011 09:32PM - edited Dec 22, 2011 09:53PM by lisa-e The fitter I saw when I got mast bras and forms was pretty good.  She didn't feed me any lines about needing to wear forms.   Even though I got the forms and they are comfortable to wear, most of the time I don't because it is too much bother.  I am always running late in the a.m. and it takes me too long to slip the forms into the bra pockets.  As I mostly wear tee shirts, no one pays any attention to my flat chest.  Yesterday I went to the dentist.  I have been seeing him for 28 years.  He asked me what drugs I am taking and what they were for.  He was surprised I was taking one for breast cancer.  I accused him of not paying attention.  He said he normally pays attention to my mouth, not the rest of my body.  :-)

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2013 05:37AM lisa-e wrote: After I was diagnosed, I had a lumpectomy and excisional biopsy (same as a lumpectomy).  I had DCIS in the upper right quadrent of my breast.  I had the excisional biopsy becuase my surgeon felt a dimple on the underside of my breast.  He made a decision during surgery to remove what ever whas causing the dimple.  Turned out it was a good idea, as it was a small IDC tumor (didn't show up on a mammogram).  My doctors all agreed that as I had good margins, I didn't need a mastectomy.  The rad onc I saw mentioned studies that survival rates for women who had two lumpectomies and rads were the same as women who had mastecomies.  She felt the major reason to have a mastectomy was cosmetic.  I was very busty and my breast looked much the same after the two lumpectomies.   My rad onc asked me to have an MRI before beginning radiation, to check for the extent of disease.  I had another IDC tumor and an area of DCIS.  These areas were in a different quadrent than the original two tumors and a mastecomy was recommended.  I didn't have radiation.   So it possible to have two lumpectomies.  I'd get second opinions before having surgery if you are unsure of the doctors recommendations.
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed now MRI finds a 2nd Lump jfelice Camillia

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2013 12:29PM lisa-e wrote: This was a study where women with out a history of breast cancer were asked to choose treament options, based on a scenario described by the doctor.  As discribed to them all of the treatment options had the same out come.  This, in my mind is not really a useful study as it only addresses the name used for DCIS.   It does nothing to address the understanding of which cases of safely be monitored and which need treatment.

Posts.Title: Lymphedema discussions during BC awareness month kap24 Binney4

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2009 11:38AM lisa-e wrote: Christine, even if you think you will be relieved to not have breasts, it still sucks to be facing a mastectomy. To be honest, I would have preferred to have a lumpectomy, but had to have a mastectomy as my bc was discovered to be multi-centric after my initial surgery. Like you I was quite busty, so I decided to have a bilateral. I do miss my breasts, but do have the consolation of knowing I didn't have any other options. I decided against reconstruction because I wanted to minimize any surgery. I had a total hip replacement a month before i was dx with bc in addition to a lumpectomy, an excisional biopsy and SNB. I was tired and couldn't imagine going through reconstruction. Also, I am a climber and hike a lot. I really did not want implants under my pecs or to have another major scar from a flap surgery. I am reasonably pleased with the appearance of my chest. My surgeon asked a plastic surgeon to help with the surgery, so i didn't wind up with dog ears or extra skin. My scars run from my sternum to under my arms. There are also smaller scars that run from what was the nipple area to the main scar. My range of motion is normal and I have been able to resume climbing and hiking. However, I do have a lot of adhesions and my chest usually feels tight. As the scar from my hip replacement also has some adhesions, I think that is just the way my body heals. I massage the scars, stretch a lot and even after a year I still notice some changes. I find the Breast Free site very helpful: breastfree.org/ Good luck! I think you will find the transition to being flat chested to be interesting, some hilarious moments, some sad moments, but doable.
Posts.Title: Surgery on Oct 1st-- double masectomy, no reconstruction.. Christine2000 delaine

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2010 01:50PM lisa-e wrote: I agree with bomber410.  I have mild le and have been able to day hike without making my le worse.   I use daypacks with a good support system and a hip belt, so most of the weight is on my hips, not hanging from my shoulders.  I wear a compression shirt when I hike and also use hiking pole.  The hiking poles really help with dependent edema, which I got pre bilat mast and le.    I tried a fanny pack. It worked for carrying a few items, but it didn't work when it was fully loaded with stuff for a day hike as it would slip down.  Very annoying.    I have seen messenger bags that are designed so the strap is positioned diagonally across your body, ie the strap goes over one shoulder and the bag rests on the opposite hip.  That may work for you.  I have seen people hiking with similarly designed packs.
Posts.Title: Backpack after Mastectomy and node removal karenn OneBadBoob

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2011 06:43PM lisa-e wrote: It has been about three years since my BMX.  At this point I am used to the way I look.  I am not thrilled my flat state but I don't think about it that much.     I rarely wear forms - too much of a bother.    I like to wear button down shirts over a tank top or cami.  How dressy or feminine I look depends on the material - silk or linen are dressy, while cotton is less so.     I also wear tee shirts a lot, but don't limit the colors.  I like wear earrings and bracelets as they help me feel more femine and are fun.   You might might want to look at the breast free site to look at ideas how to dress: http://www.breastfree.org/

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 05:55PM lisa-e wrote: Susanne,  I've never taken neurotin, but my son did for many years, so I am somewhat familiar with it.   You should talk to the prescribing doctor about interpersing it with other drugs.  When you start taking it you often have to ramp up to the desired dose and there are issues (anxiety for one) when you decrease your dosage so you have to taper off.  I don't know if your plan will work or not.
Posts.Title: pain management/mental health Suzybelle kcshreve

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2010 11:50PM lisa-e wrote: lizzymack1, you may not 'need' your breasts once you are beyone child reating, but they are still a sexaul organ and can be a source of pleasure both for you and for your partner. I had a matectomy because I had multicentric cancer and it was the only surgical option available to me. I am well beyond my child rearing years but I still miss my breasts. A mastectomy is major surgery, with or without reconstruction. You can have permanent side effects including numbness, nerve damage (look for the thread on post mastectomy pain syndrome) and lymphedema. Also, it is not a gaurantee you will not have a local or distant recurrence. And you don't get a do over if you don't like the result. Therefore, I think limegreen is right, you should consider the medical reasons for preferring a mastectomy over a lumpectomy. I would ask your doctors what they recommend and why they are making that recomendation. Then I would get a second opinion before making any decisions.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2009 04:53PM lisa-e wrote: Kathi, that pictures is so, so funny.  But you do look great!!  When I wear things with an empire style waiste, I look pregnant.  My shoulders and rib cage are very wide, so I think the best style for me are either button down shirts or tunics.  Tee shirts look okay on me too.  I am lucky I don't have to get dressed up for work.  I notice the lack of boobs more when I wear dressy clothing - I often wind up wearing forms then.
Posts.Title: Wardrobe pics for boobless days mom2two ShadePink

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2009 01:04PM lisa-e wrote: Judy,  I have prosthetics but normally don't wear them.   They are comfortable, but it is much simpler to go without.  I can throw on a tee shirt and am out the door, versus dealing with the prosthetics, mastectomy bras and pockets.    I don't feel obligated to wear the prosthetics - they are more like toys to me, a way to play with my appearance.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 01:31PM lisa-e wrote: I just had a discussion about this with my rheumatologist.  He wanted to take my blood pressure so I told him that he would need to use a thigh cuff.  He didn't have one, so was unhappy about being twarted.  He said he thinks it is silly to think that a taking blood pressure could trigger a flare up of LE.  I pointed out there were no studies indicating it was safe - he was unhappy.  I told him I have to answer to my LE therapist.
Posts.Title: My arm surgeon stavmom stavmom

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2009 09:50PM - edited Jun 30, 2009 09:51PM by lisa-e Even better than the sleeves are jovi packs. Stops the nurses and aides dead in their tracks. Ask me how I know . . . I was admitted to the hopsital on Saturday for cellulitits in my shin. I had my iv in my foot as my le is bilateral. I never had a fever or felt ill. If I hadn't looked at my leg on Thursday night when I undressed, I wouldn 't have known I had it. I watched it for a while and realized it wasn't spreading fast, if at all, so decided to skip the emergency room in favor or seeing the doctor first thing in the morning. The doctor admited me after oral anti-biotics and shots didn't work. I am glad she decided to get agressive because I was worried about my artifical hip - same leg. If my prosthesis became infected, I would be toast. Luckily, it is fine - they did xrays and a ct scan. Jo, I hope you are feeling better soon and survive the antibiotics. Lisa

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2009 04:01PM lisa-e wrote: Interesting about the tightness.  I feel tight all of the time if I am not wearing some form of compression (compression shirt, mast bra with forms, or a jovi pack).  I assume that the tightness is related to my le.   I do feel less tight after exercise - whether or not I wear a compression shirt.  I usually wear one when exercising but not always.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2009 08:16PM lisa-e wrote: SuzNY,  when I had my hip replacement they used disolvable stitches for the internal stitching.  I had what my surgeon's pa called spitting stitches for months.  It felt like I had bits of fishing line coming out of my skin, but they didn't do anything about them other telling me it wasn't a big deal.  If you don't have any signs of infection, I don't think it would be a problem to wait until you see the PS next week to ask about the stitch.
Posts.Title: omg...there is still a stitch! What should I do? cookiegal Sassa

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2008 02:41PM - edited Oct 29, 2008 02:42PM by lisa-e I had a bilateral mastectomy without reconstruction about 5 weeks ago, so I am still in the healing phase.  I was very busty before the mastectomy and even though a plastic surgeon helped my surgeon plan the incisions so I would have have a good cosmetic result, the scars are long.   My range of motion has been effected so I am starting physical therapy and I expect that to help. I am happy with my decision and think I look fine without a prosthesis.   While I have gotten a few puzzled looks from casual friends (male, of course) I don't think most people notice anything odd about my appearance.  When I can start wearing a prosthesis, I'll get one to wear if I want to wear clothing that would look better if I had 'breasts'.   Reading the threads on this site and looking at BreastFree helped me feel comfortable with my decision not to have reconstruction.   When I was considering reconstruction versus no reconstruction , my surgeon referred me to a plastic surgeon so I could make an 'informed decision.'   The plastic surgeon had me watch a video about reconstruction.  As I think a truly informed decision can only be made with input about all options,  I should have also been required to watch a video about opting out of reconstruction.
Posts.Title: reconstruction or not ????? vivianu spar2

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2012 11:56AM lisa-e wrote: Your diagnosis line indicates your initial diagnosis was a small area of low grade DCIS (Ductoral Cancer in Situ).  I would think with your co-morbity you would want to have the least possible treatment to effectively treat your non-invasive cancer.  A double mastectomy is not an easy surgery and not something to be jumped into lightly.  I would get several opinions on your surgical options and your treatment options.  In addition, I think I would talk to the doctor(s) who treats your AIDS before starting any treatment and seeing what they say.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with BC. AIDS for 20+yrs. StayinAlive68 Shachar

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2009 10:22PM lisa-e wrote: To my surgeon, I am really glad you felt a dimple and removed the IDC that did not show up on a mammogram. When you mentioned the dimple to me during the exam, I didn't ask you about its significance. I should have, because I woke up with three scars instead of the two I expected. To my radiation oncologist, I am really glad you asked me to get an MRI to check for the extent of disease before I started radiation. Good idea, considering I had another IDC that didn't show up on the mammogram. To my oncologist, I wish you had suggested the MRI after I was first diagnosed with DCIS. I asked you about one and you said you didn't think it was necessary as there were too many false positives. I was more than willing to go along with your thinking, so I have not held that against you. However, I do resent the fact that you could not remember if I had large breasts or not when we discussed my mastectomy over the phone. At that point you had met and examined me twice.
Posts.Title: Dear doctor, I wish ... mawhinney 2frogs1princess

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2015 02:51PM lisa-e wrote: Busymom, I am glad you are getting a second opinion. My BS felt a dimple (indent) and decided to remove what ever was causing the dimple when I had a lumpectomy for DCIS. What was causing the dimple was a smallish invasive ductal carcinoma. This tumor was not seen when I had a diagnostic mammogram. Dimples in the breast can be caused by tumors and should be investigated.
Posts.Title: mammogram clear but still worried as indent on breast Busymum2015 evey40

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 02:32PM lisa-e wrote:  My dh was mis-diagnosed with asthma after he had pneumonia.   He saw a pulmonologist who correctly diagnosed him as having chronic bronchitis, secondary to the pneumonia.  His medication was changed and he recovered completely.  On  the other hand my dad does have adult onset asthma.  His major syptom is coughing.  So it is good you are seeng a pulmonogist.
Posts.Title: Dumb questions about my onco. visit Suzybelle Suzybelle

Posts.Content: May 6, 2012 09:32PM lisa-e wrote: Otter,  I can totally understand why you are crabby.  Two of the people who responded to your question are women who have had reconstruction.  The most pressure I have had regarding reconstruction have been from women who have  reconstruction.  They can't believe my reasons for not having reconstruction are valid.  I don't understand as I don't question their decisions. When I was deciding whether or not to have reconstruction, I asked my husband for his opinion.  He wouldn't tell me, because he did want to influence me.  As it turns out, he initially though I should have reconstruction.  But as I talked to him about my decision, he understood and accepted it.   My husband has seen my scars from the beginning and I don't hide them.   I don't think he is repulsed or bothered by them.    I don't think being my flat has affected our sex lives.  The major problem is I have no libido after taking anti-hormonals for three years.  My husband has his own sexual issues.  In a way we are well matched... :-) Baywatcher, I don't know where you are in treatment or if you are taking anti-hormonal drugs, but I was in a grey, miserable fog when I took tomoxifen.  Just saying . . . I hate to see you so sad.
